channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Xi Jinping Is Rewriting China's History
item.description: A new official summation of Communist Party history is likely to exalt Xi Jinping as a peer of Mao and Deng, fortifying his claim to a new phase in power.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, giving a speech last month in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: In Nicaragua Election, Ortega Crushes Dissent
item.description: President Daniel Ortega quashed the opposition and struck fear in voters, all but guaranteeing his victory in a presidential contest on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Yubelka Mendoza and Natalie Kitroeff
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A campaign poster for President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua and his wife and running mate, Rosario Murillo. Mr. Ortega has effectively outlawed any opposition to his candidacy.

item.title: French Clerical Abuse Report Puts Spotlight on Confession
item.description: In rare instances, it noted, the secrecy around the sacrament had been used to cover up abuse cases, again raising issues of whether church or state law should prevail.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The report recommended that priests who heard of abuse during confession should be required to report evidence to state authorities.

item.title: Fears of Wider Instability in Iraq After Attack on Prime Minister’s Home
item.description: Armed drones struck the Iraqi prime minister’s home in what was seen as a warning as Iranian-backed groups dispute the results of parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Iraqi Prime Minister Media Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi at a polling station in Baghdad’s Green Zone on Election Day last month. He was largely unharmed in the attack on Sunday.

item.title: On Tiny Guam, It’s One Dogcatcher vs. 30,000 Strays
item.description: They bite, they threaten, they carry the risk of rabies. Islanders are sharply divided over what to do about the dogs. And Nicholas Ibanez is caught in the middle.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho
item.media:credit: Anthony Henri Oftana for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stray dogs in Guam are responsible for attacks on people and pets, and carry the threat of rabies.

item.title: India's Treatment of Muslims Erodes Its Moral High Ground
item.description: The hard-line attitude of Narendra Modi’s ruling party toward Muslims has undermined the nation’s reputation as a voice for tolerance in South Asia.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hindus in Bangladesh protesting the violent attacks against them in Dhaka last month.

item.title: On Spain’s Camino de Santiago, Even Óscar the Donkey Is a Pilgrim
item.description: An artist and an innkeeper have enlisted the help of a burro in their effort to rescue the traditions of Spain’s ancient pilgrimage route from mass tourism (and selfies).
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irene García-Inés, an artist, and Jesus Jato, an innkeeper, on the Camino de Santiago with Óscar, their burro.

item.title: Tanker Truck Explodes in Sierra Leone, Killing at Least 98
item.description: The truck first started leaking fuel and people had rushed to collect it, an official said. Many of them died in the blast, along with others nearby.
item.dc:creator: Jaime Yaya Barry and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: The site of the explosion in Freetown, Sierra Leone, on Saturday. The blast on Friday night also set fire to a gas station.

item.title: Spanish Police Seek Missing Plane Passengers After Emergency Landing
item.description: More than 20 people fled a Moroccan flight that diverted to Mallorca after a passenger apparently fell ill. A dozen had yet to be found.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Travelers boarding a bus at Palma de Mallorca airport in Spain after an Air Arabia Maroc flight made an emergency landing on Friday. About 20 others fled.

item.title: COP26 Protesters Back an Array of Causes, Connected by Climate Change
item.description: Thousands gathered in the rain in Glasgow to press the case for more urgent and meaningful action by world leaders in response to global warming.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters marched through Glasgow on Saturday.

item.title: Near-Daily Covid Tests, Sleeping in Classrooms: Life in Covid-Zero China
item.description: Residents in Ruili, in southwestern China, have been locked down four times in the past year as part of the country’s quest to eliminate the virus.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Ruili, China, in July. The city has been locked down four times in the past year.

item.title: Eight Groups Join Tigray Rebels Vowing to Oust Ethiopia’s Leader
item.description: The government calls the new coalition, announced in Washington, a “publicity stunt,” as intermediaries try to negotiate a peaceful solution to a year of conflict.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Berhane Gebre-Christos of the Tigray People’s Liberation Front at a news conference in Washington on Friday. He urged a resolution “before Ethiopia implodes and affects the region.”

item.title: First Black Woman in Bundestag Wants to Change Image of ‘Germanness’
item.description: After a deadly racist attack, Awet Tesfaiesus considered leaving Germany. Instead, she ran for Parliament with a “courage to change” slogan and won.
item.dc:creator: Ian Bateson
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Awet Tesfaiesus was elected this September to Parliament as a member of the Green Party, becoming the first Black woman in Germany to ever win a seat in the Bundestag.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: China’s new official history.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People in Shanghai watched a broadcast of China’s President Xi Jinping speaking on Thursday.

item.title: Afghan Military Pilots, on the Run, Feel Abandoned by U.S.
item.description: Detained in Tajikistan, or hiding from the Taliban in Afghanistan, many pilots wonder why the military that trained them is not coming to their aid.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan Air Force training exercise in Logar Province in 2018. The United States spent billions of dollars training and equipping Afghan forces.

item.title: Young Marines in Kabul Were Left to Run Final Days of Evacuation
item.description: The young Marines in Kabul were left to determine who was evacuated from Afghanistan and who was left behind. The cost was high.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Capt. Andres Rodriguez and Capt. Geoff Ball were at Abbey Gate in Kabul when a suicide bomber struck during the final days of U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan.

item.title: U.K. Health Secretary Urges People to Get Boosters
item.description: “If we all come together and play our part, we can get through this challenging winter, avoid a return to restrictions and enjoy Christmas,” said Sajid Javid, the health secretary.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Ten million Britons have received the booster vaccinations.

item.title: What’s in a Name? For the Koreans of Sakhalin, an Anguished History
item.description: Stranded for decades on the island in Russia’s Far East, some bear three names, Japanese, Russian and Korean, representing different historical chapters. Now, many are planning their return.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibit on South Korean clothing and handcrafts at the Sakhalin Art Museum. The island in Russia’s Far East is suffused with Korean culture.

item.title: As U.S. Travel Changes Near, Global Travelers Eagerly Await Reunions
item.description: On Monday, travelers from many other countries who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus will be allowed to enter the United States.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: International travelers from many countries were barred from entering the United States in the early months of pandemic in 2020. On Monday, fully vaccinated travelers from abroad can return.

item.title: Veteran U.S. Diplomat Comes Under Criticism for a Trip to Myanmar
item.description: Bill Richardson, a former ambassador to the U.N., said that he had held “productive” talks with the general who led the February coup. Rights activists said he gave the junta an air of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Bill Richardson in 2018. He said that he went to Myanmar last week to try to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid, including Covid vaccines.

item.title: Antarctica Was Once a Land of Fire and Not Ice
item.description: Charcoal recovered from a dig near the southern continent shows that the region wasn’t spared from the era scientists call a “super fire world.”
item.dc:creator: Emily Cataneo

item.title: Biden's Vaccine Mandate Temporarily Blocked, Foreshadowing Uphill Battle
item.description: A stay granted by a federal appeals court in Louisiana could signal an uphill battle for the administration in getting the entire American work force vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Wednesday. The president’s vaccine mandate for large employers suffered a legal setback on Saturday.

item.title: Uyghurs Seek Emotional Help as Families in China Suffer
item.description: As Uyghurs grapple with the emotional trauma of their families suffering back in Xinjiang, some are overcoming a cultural stigma to seek out counseling.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mustafa Aksu reached out to a therapist to help him deal with the trauma he experienced over the deaths of his relatives in Xinjiang, China.

item.title: A fire in Covid intensive care ward kills 11 people in India.
item.description: Staff at the hospital in the western state of Maharashtra tried to douse the fire with fire extinguishers, but the flames spread quickly in the airtight room.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: A Covid-19 ward caught fire Saturday in Ahmednagar, a city in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. Officials said eleven patients died and others were injured.

item.title: Costa Rica moves to require Covid shots for children.
item.description: The Central American nation’s health ministry said on Friday it was adding Covid-19 to the list of required vaccinations for people 18 and younger.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: A fist-bump from President Carlos Alvarado Quesada at a vaccination site in San Jose, Costa Rica, last month.

item.title: Facing a spike in infections, Austria sharpens the rules of its Covid pass.
item.description: Austrians will need proof of vaccination or a past infection to be seated at a restaurant, enter a bar, visit a hairdresser or join any gathering of more than 25 people.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Askin Kiyagan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vienna in April. Across Austria starting Monday, a negative test will not be enough to sit down in a restaurant, enter a bar or get a haircut.

item.title: Activists hope protests will draw large crowds as leaders haggle in Glasgow.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at George Square in central Glasgow on Friday.

item.title: Marília Mendonça, Brazilian Pop Singer, Dies in Plane Crash at 26
item.description: Ms. Mendonça, who was a social media sensation with millions of followers, was iconic in a type of Brazilian country music called sertanejo.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Will Dias/Futura Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The singer Marília Mendonça performing in Sao Jose dos Campos, Brazil, in September. She died on Friday in a plane crash.

item.title: Manitoba's New Premier Faces Court Challenge by Rival
item.description: The litigation highlights the often messy process that Canadian political parties use to select their leaders.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Forks district in Winnipeg, Manitoba’s capital

item.title: U.N. Rights Panel Pressures Sudan Over Coup
item.description: The Human Rights Council appointed an expert to investigate abuses in the country since the military seized power on Oct. 25, and members called for the prime minister’s release.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrating last week in the capital, Khartoum, against the Sudanese military’s recent seizure of power and ouster of the civilian government.

item.title: As Turkey Chafes at Erdogan, He Gets Spikier Abroad
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan canceled an appearance at the global climate talks over a perceived slight, part of a pattern of creating international dramas to bolster his domestic standing.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan last month at the Group of 20 summit in Rome. He was expected to attend the global climate summit in Glasgow shortly after.

item.title: John Kerry Lauds Progress at COP26 but Warns, ‘Job Not Done.’
item.description: Mr. Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, acknowledged that many of the promises being put forward in Glasgow were only that — promises.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: John Kerry, center, President Biden’s climate envoy, at COP26 on Thursday. “We all need to be pressing our ambition going forward,” he said on Friday.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Assails Leaders Outside COP26 Climate Summit
item.description: “The governments of the global north countries are still refusing to take any drastic climate action,” she told protesters in Glasgow.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Stephen Castle and Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Greta Thunberg after speaking at a demonstration in Glasgow on Friday. Leaders are “actively creating loopholes” to benefit themselves, she said.

item.title: Vanessa Nakate, Ugandan Climate Activist, Offers an Optimistic Vision
item.description: The 24-year-old from Uganda has emerged as a leading voice of young people agitating for climate action.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: “We are in a disaster that is happening every day,” Vanessa Nakate told a rally in George Square in Glasgow on Friday.

item.title: Germany's Economy Hindered by Supply Chain Problems
item.description: The order books in Europe’s largest economy are full, but a lack of parts and raw materials means companies are struggling to fill them.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Workers prepare walls for an RV camper at the Knaus-Tabbert factory in Jandelsbrunn, Germany. Supply chain issues continue to hinder manufacturers.

item.title: Ex-Macron Aide Convicted of Assault and Posing as a Police Officer
item.description: The aide, Alexandre Benalla, who was fired in 2018 after videos emerged of him beating a man at a labor protest, was sentenced to serve a year of house arrest with electronic monitoring.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Alexandre Benalla, a former aide to President Emmanuel Macron of France, arriving for trial in Paris on Monday.

item.title: 11 States Sue Over Biden's Vaccine Mandate for Big Companies
item.description: The lawsuit was filed a day after the announcement of a Jan. 4 deadline for the companies to begin their mandates or start weekly testing.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin
item.media:description: Attorney General Eric Schmitt of Missouri in St. Louis in 2020.

item.title: Vienna Will Start to Vaccinate Young Children
item.description: Pediatricians in the Austrian capital will authorize the off-label use of the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine for children starting next Friday.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A Covid vaccination center in Vienna in February.

item.title: Mothers Demand Action on Air Pollution at COP26
item.description: A letter to world leaders gathered at the U.N. climate conference in Glasgow was signed by nearly 500 parent groups from 44 countries.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Rosamund Kissi-Debrah’s daughter died from an asthma attack in Britain in 2013.

item.title: Rights Groups Urge Singapore Not to Execute Man With Mental Disability
item.description: The man, a Malaysian with an I.Q. of 69, was caught trying to smuggle an ounce and a half of heroin in 2009. Some are calling his planned hanging a human rights violation.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: People in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Wednesday protesting Singapore’s planned execution next week of Nagaenthran Dharmalingam.

item.title: Turning Back the Clock
item.description: After a busy week, we offer six stories that caught our eyes.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A bookmobile in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in 1967.

item.title: Japan Will Cut Quarantine for Business Travelers to 3 Days
item.description: The easing of rules comes as cases decline significantly. The country has virtually closed its borders since the start of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Makiko Inoue
item.media:description: South Korean athletes began the quarantine process for the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games after arriving at Narita International Airport in July. Japan’s border restrictions remain some of the strictest in the region.

item.title: At COP26, Youth Want Action, Accountability as Protesters Rally
item.description: For many, the climate conference has inspired mixed emotions: concern that their voices were not really being listened to, but also hope that their presence would help drive change.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered beside Kelvingrove Park in Glasgow on Friday.

item.title: In India, Fears Grow That Diwali Celebrations Could Fuel Another Virus Spike
item.description: Epidemiologists are concerned that Covid cases will surge after shoppers thronged markets and hundreds of thousands traveled around the country to celebrate the festival.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Along the Sarayu River in Ayodhya, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Nuclear-Powered Shower? Russia Tests a Climate Innovation.
item.description: A remote Siberian town now has its own miniature nuclear plant as a Russian state company tests a new model for residential heating. Some see it as a tool to minimize climate change.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pavel Rozhkov showering with water heated by a nuclear reactor.

item.title: Laughs No More? Australians Are Reassessing a Beloved Cartoonist.
item.description: I used to think Michael Leunig’s drawings embodied the soul of our nation. Now, I’m not so sure.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:description: Michael Leunig’s drawing of the writer and her mother.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A Covid hot spot in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Police officers sprayed water jets at protesters in Trieste last month.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in November
item.description: Our picks for November, including ‘tick, tick … BOOM!’, ‘The Great’ Season 2, and ‘Passing’
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: In Saskatoon, a Moose on the Loose Is Returned to the Wild
item.description: In a prairie city, a young moose on the loose crashed into a children’s classroom, sparking a mix of delight and concern on social media.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: A White House aide who traveled abroad with Biden tests positive.
item.description: President Biden was not in close contact with the aide, who remains quarantined in Scotland and has not shown symptoms of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, leaving for Europe last week. The president, who is 78, received a booster shot in September.

item.title: Canada Turns Over Military Sexual Assault Cases to Civilian Courts
item.description: With the military’s leadership in crisis, a new defense minister adopted a recommendation to remove prosecutorial authority for sexual misconduct cases from the armed forces.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:description: Canada’s minister of national defense, Anita Anand, at a news conference last month.

item.title: Clash With Corruption Watchdog Has Boris Johnson Retreating, Again
item.description: Britain’s prime minister intervened in the case of a Conservative Party lawmaker who faced suspension. A ferocious blowback caused him to retreat, a now familiar path.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Boris Johnson in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: U.S. sets deadlines for vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mario Pinera received a coronavirus vaccine at a vaccine clinic in Anchorage, Alaska, last week.

item.title: Crackdown Sweeps Ethiopia’s Capital as War Draws Near
item.description: Government forces were going to door to door in the Ethiopian capital, rounding up ethnic Tigrayans, members of the same ethnic group as the rebels closing in.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: New Ethiopian military recruits gathered for ceremony at a stadium in Addis Ababa, where the mayor bade them farewell.

item.title: With Fish, Trucks and Submarines, U.K. and France Bicker Over Brexit
item.description: A recent dispute over fishing rights illuminates a broader and more fundamental disagreement over Britain’s decision to leave the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and President Emmanuel Macron of France met in Rome last week as the two nations sparred over fishing rights.
